Package it.polimi.ingsw.controller.commands

Class PlayerCommand

java.lang.Object
it.polimi.ingsw.controller.commands.Command
it.polimi.ingsw.controller.commands.PlayerCommand
All Implemented Interfaces:
java.io.Serializable
public class PlayerCommand
extends Command
In this class there are references to the player who is playing the current turn during the Real Game phase, the type of Command requested by the player, the worker he/she wants to move or build with and the cell in which the player wants to move or build in.
See Also:
Serialized Form

  • Field Details

    • workerID

      public final java.lang.String workerID
      The ID of the Worker. It will be either Command.WORKER_FIRST or Command.WORKER_SECOND.

    • row

      public final int row
      The Row/Column identifier that is used to identify the Cell in which the Player wants to move his/her Worker, or where the Worker wants to build a new level.

    • col

      public final int col

    • cellBlockType

      public final BlockType cellBlockType
      This is an optional parameter which indicates which level the player wants to build.

    • worker

      private transient Worker worker
      This properties must be reconstructed by server-side Controller.

    • cell

      private transient Cell cell

  • Constructor Details

    • PlayerCommand

      public PlayerCommand​(CommandType commandType, java.lang.String workerID, int row, int col, BlockType cellBlockType)
      PlayerCommand is the constructor of the class. It sets the class' attributes such as the CommandType (CommandType.MOVE, CommandType.BUILD, ...), the interested worker, the destination-cell of move/build and an optional level (in case of building a block).
      Parameters:
      commandType - the type of Command, specific of RealGame phase
      workerID - ID of worker to move/build with; null if the operation involves no worker (such as an end of turn)
      row - an integer representing the row of cell where to move/build in; possible values are from 0 to number of rows in Board minus one; -1 if the operation involves no cell (such as an end of turn)
      col - an integer representing the column of cell where to move/build in; possible values are from 0 to number of columns in Board minus one; -1 if the operation involves no cell (such as an end of turn)
      cellBlockType - the type of block that the player wants to build; null if the operation is not a build, or the player wants to build the default level (so he/she wants to build just one level higher)

  • Method Details

    • setCell

      public void setCell​(Cell cell)
      This method is the setter for "cell" property, that must be reconstructed by server-side Controller.
      Parameters:
      cell - the cell where to move/build in

    • getCell

      public Cell getCell()
      This method is the getter for "cell" property, that is reconstructed by server-side Controller.
      Returns:
      the cell where to move/build in

    • getWorker

      public Worker getWorker()
      This method is the getter for "worker" property, that is reconstructed by server-side Controller.
      Returns:
      the worker that is going to move/build

    • setWorker

      public void setWorker​(Worker worker)
      This method is the setter for "worker" property, that must be reconstructed by server-side Controller.
      Parameters:
      worker - the worker that is going to move/build

    • handleCommand

      public void handleCommand​(CommandHandler handler)
      This method handles the PlayerCommand received by Server in the proper way.
      Specified by:
      handleCommand in class Command
      Parameters:
      handler - the object that is going to handle the command

    • parseInput

      public static PlayerCommand parseInput​(java.lang.String command) throws BadCommandException
      Static method used to parse a String command input by the user (CLI) into a PlayerCommand instance using String-rep for Workers.
      Parameters:
      command - input String taken from Standard Input
      Returns:
      the corresponding PlayerCommand instance (if the command is well formatted)
      Throws:
      BadCommandException - if the command String is not well formatted
